headline: LiveTransfer news LIVE: Man Utd in Ugarte talks, Gallagher completes Chelsea exit, Gundogan back to Man City
body: Manchester United have stepped up the pursuit of Manuel Ugarte after missing out on Burnley's Sander Berge, while there are developments on Raheem Sterling and Eddie Nketiah
There are still some huge deals left to be done in the summer transfer window.

Manchester United are desperate for a new central midfielder and are prepared to bide their time for Paris Saint-Germain star Manuel Ugarte after Fulham made a bid worth £25million for Burnley's Sander Berge.

The soap opera continues at Chelsea, who need to offload players after agreeing to sign Joao Felix for £36m from Atletico Madrid. The deal will allow Conor Gallagher to move in the other direction - and could spark the departure of Raheem Sterling and five other unwanted Chelsea players.
Arsenal are finally close to bringing in Real Sociedad's Mikel Merino and rejected a first bid of £25m from Nottingham Forest for Eddie Nketiah.
Follow all the latest from those deals - and lots more - on the Mirror Football live transfer blog...
Arsenal are closing in on the signing of Mikel Merino.

Merino was left out of Real Sociedad’s first game of the season on Sunday, with Arsenal in negotiations to acquire his services. Arsenal sporting director Edu has flown out to Spain to work on the deal after he became Mikel Arteta's top transfer target following the arrival of Riccardo Calafiori.

Negotiations now centre on the transfer fee involved after La Real turned down Arsenal’s first bid of €25milion (£21.4m). The Spanish side are holding out for €35m (£30m) for the 28-year-old midfielder, who has one year left on his contract.
Liverpool are closing in on a deal for Giori Mamardashvili - and that could pave the way for Caoimhin Kelleher to leave Anfield.
Mamardashvili is expected to sign in a £34million deal as Alisson's long-term successor.
And The Independent claim his arrival could lead to Kelleher moving on - even though Mamardashvili won't officially join the Reds until next summer.
Ipswich Town are set to sign Armando Broja on loan from Chelsea.
The Albania striker, 23, is surplus to requirements at Stamford Bridge and has been given the green light to leave.
And Broja will now link up with Kieran McKenna's side per a new report from The EADT.
Leeds, Marseille, two Premier League sides and one from Serie A are all interested in signing Norwich City's Jonathan Rowe, according to L’Équipe.
Rowe got 12 goals and two assists in 32 Championship appearances last season for Norwich and is a wanted man.
Marseille have reportedly seen two bids rejected, but still lead the race ahead of Leeds, who want a replacement for Crysencio Summerville, who left in a £35million move to West Ham.
West Ham have agreed a deal with Paris FC for Mohamadou Kante.
The 18-year-old midfielder will become the Hammers' ninth summer signing once he passes a medical - but he is not expected to feature under head coach Julen Lopetegui this season.
Kante, who will sign a five-year contract, is being acquired as a long-term project and a return to Paris on loan has not yet been ruled out.
West Ham have already spent more than £120m on revamping their squad following Lopetegui’s arrival as replacement for David Moyes.
Centre half Max Kilman, winger Crysencio Summerville and striker Niclas Fullkrug are among the new faces in East London.
They also remain keen on securing a loan-to-buy deal for PSG’s Carlos Soler.

But Kurt Zouma, who captained the side last season, is expected to leave before next week’s deadline. The former France defender, who earns six-figures a week, is of interest to clubs in Saudi Arabia.
Conor Gallagher has been given the green light to fly to Spain and complete his protracted transfer to Atletico Madrid, per The Athletic.
The Chelsea midfielder had looked set to join the La Liga outfit earlier this month and was even pictured at Atletico's stadium before the deal was cast into doubt.
But with Atletico now set to sell Joao Felix to Chelsea, they can finalise the 24-year-old's €42million (£32.3m) switch.
Lamine Bogarde has signed a new contract with Aston Villa.
The highly-rated defender has been linked with a loan move this summer and it's thought he could depart Villa Park on a temporary basis.
But while it remains to be seen if the 20-year-old will head out or not, Bogarde has been rewarded with fresh terms.
Portsmouth are set to announce the signing of goalkeeper Nicolas Schmid.
The 27-year-old Austrian shot-stopper is joining Pompey from Linz on a permanent basis and will battle with Will Norris for the No.1 jersey.
Millwall have wrapped up a deal for Celtic prodigy Daniel Kelly.

The talented 18-year-old midfielder was sought after by a host of clubs after rejecting a new contract offer from the Scottish champions but penned a pre-contract agreement with Lions earlier this month.
Millwall and Celtic have since thrashed out a deal for Kelly to move south now rather than in January and the youngster has now completed the formalities of said switch.
Ilkay Gundogan is open to returning to Manchester City this summer as his Barcelona future grows more uncertain.
According to The Telegraph, he is expected to leave the club before the end of the transfer window. Barcelona need to sell in order to be able to register Dani Olmo.
Gundogan only joined the Spanish giants last summer after leaving Man City at the end of his contract.
Sticking with newly-promoted clubs, Leicester have announced that winger Kasey McAteer has signed a new deal with the club. He is now tied to the 2016 Premier League champions until 2028.

He said: "Everyone knows what playing for Leicester City means to me having been here at the Football Club for most of my life, so to sign a new contract after such an incredible 12 months is a dream come true.

“It’s such a special club and there’s so much excitement around the place going into the new Premier League season. I’m so happy to be part of it and I’ll be giving everything to play my part in helping the team achieve all we can on the pitch.”
McAteer scored seven goals for Leicester last season.
Lazio have not yet dropped their interest in Southampton star Charly Alcaraz.
According to Gazzetta dello Sport, the Italian side still want to sign him before the end of the window and are aiming to sign him on an initial loan deal with an obligation to buy between €10-12m.
Alcaraz spent last season on loan with Juventus.
Wolves are battling with Brentford to sign Burnley’s Republic of Ireland defender Dara O’Shea.
O’Shea, 25, impressed with his creativity last season, despite Burnley’s relegation, and Wolves are looking at the centre-half to replace Max Kilman, who has joined West Ham for £40million.
The Clarets would not stand in O’Shea’s way, but they would want £15million for him after paying his £7million release clause at West Brom last summer.
Brentford are also keen and Burnley are determined he will only leave if their asking price is met.

Burnley have seen Sander Berge leave for Fulham and the Cottagers have agreed a fee of £20million, rising to £25million with add-ons, for the Norway midfielder. Burnley want to replace him with Manchester United’s Tunisia international Hannibal Mejbri.
Mejbri, 21, played in United’s 1-0 win at Turf Moor last September and is surplus to requirements at Old Trafford as he enters the final 12 months of his deal.
He made only six appearances for Sevilla during an ill-fated loan spell during the second half of last season and Burnley are considering a loan or permanent bid.
Paris Saint-Germain could reportedly be booted out of the Champions League if they do not pay Kylian Mbappe €55million (£47m) unpaid wages.
Mbappe's lawyers say he is due the final payment of a €36m signing bonus, the last three months of his salary and an ‘ethics bonus’ for the period of April-June 2024.

Le Monde reports that Mbappe’s lawyers have gone to the committee of the Ligue de Football Professionnel (LFP) and to European football’s governing body at UEFA over the dispute which has occurred since Mbappe left PSG on a free transfer to join Real Madrid.
Manchester United are still hopeful they can offload Jadon Sancho before the end of the summer transfer window.

The Athletic says that sources as United 'sense' that Chelsea could be interested - despite them already shelling out £54million on Pedro Neto, £36m on Joao Felix and having so many options in wide areas that Raheem Sterling has been frozen out.
Sancho is open to leaving, but his £250,000-a-week wages and £40m asking price present obvious hurdles.
Paul Heckingbottom has been confirmed as the new manager of Preston.

The former Sheffield United manager said: “I’m really delighted with it, ready to go, and champing at the bit really. It’s a club I know well for lots of reasons and a league I know well, so it was a pretty easy decision."
He replaces Ryan Lowe, who left just one game into the Championship season.
Chelsea could secure Ivan Toney for £45million after Arsenal and Manchester United ruled out a move for the Brentford striker.
Brentford had put a £70m asking price on Toney's head but have dropped it and set a deadline of this weekend for offers after rejecting an initial approach from Al-Ahli.
Chelsea remain interested in signing Napoli striker Victor Osimhen on loan, but Toney represents an alternative for them - provided they can offload some of their unwanted players first.
Ilkay Gundogan is being linked with a move back to Manchester City - and it would please his wife.
Speaking to the Daily Mail earlier this year, Sara said: "After making friends, I was really happy. I had my own life and routine in Manchester and I have one of my best friends there.

"It's always sad, especially because you make friends, you're happy somewhere, you build your life and then you have to leave all the people you love. I started to enjoy everything and I kind of miss Manchester now."
Leeds, Marseille, two Premier League sides and one from Serie A are all interested in signing Norwich City's Jonathan Rowe, according to L’Équipe.
Rowe got 12 goals and two assists in 32 Championship appearances last season for Norwich and is a wanted man.
Marseille have reportedly seen two bids rejected, but still lead the race ahead of Leeds, who want a replacement for Crysencio Summerville, who left in a £35million move to West Ham.
Burnley have shown an interest in signing Manchester United midfielder Hannibal Mejbri, according to The Athletic.

Hannibal has entered the final year of his United contract and is only on the fringes of Erik ten Hag's first team squad after spending the second half of last season on loan at Sevilla. A loan move, or a permanent transfer, are considered possible.
Romelu Lukaku is in a familiar situation, desperate to leave Chelsea before the summer transfer window closes.
He wants to be reunited with Antonio Conte at Napoli, but that move could depend on the departure of Victor Osimhen.
Lukaku is frustrated and has spent time on social media, where he's liked a post by Rio Ferdinand which criticises Chelsea's treatment of Raheem Sterling.
Southampton are poised to announce the signing of Mateus Fernandes from Sporting Lisbon, while Sekou Mara is heading to Strasbourg.
According to reports in Portugal, Fernandes has completed his medical ahead of a transfer worth €15million (£12.8m) plus €5m in add-ons.

Meanwhile, Mara has travelled to France ahead of a €12m (£10m) transfer to Strasbourg. The 22-year-old striker joined Saints in July 2022 from Bordeaux but has scored just eight goals in 64 games since then.
Scott McTominay could still leave Manchester United this summer despite Fulham aiming for Sander Berge instead.
Fulham have made an offer worth £25million for Burnley's Berge after seeing two offers rejected by United for McTominay.
However, The Athletic reports that Galatasaray, Fenerbahce and Everton are all interested. United are open to selling McTominay, but only if their valuation is met.
Arsenal are closing in on the signing of Mikel Merino.

Merino was left out of Real Sociedad’s first game of the season on Sunday, with Arsenal in negotiations to acquire his services. Arsenal sporting director Edu has flown out to Spain to work on the deal after he became Mikel Arteta's top transfer target following the arrival of Riccardo Calafiori.

Negotiations now centre on the transfer fee involved after La Real turned down Arsenal’s first bid of €25milion (£21.4m). The Spanish side are holding out for €35m (£30m) for the 28-year-old midfielder, who has one year left on his contract.
Aston Villa are interested in signing Joe Gomez from Liverpool this summer.
Gomez is Liverpool's longest serving player but considering his future after being left out of the 20-man squad to face Ipswich on Saturday.

Villa want more players for their Champions League campaign, but could be priced out of a permanent transfer, given Gomez had agreed to join Newcastle for £45million as part of the collapsed £75m swap deal for Anthony Gordon in late June.
Newcastle United have been trying very hard to sign Marc Guehi from Crystal Palace, but the situation has reached an impasse.
The latest offer of £60million plus a futher £5m in add-ons still leaves them short of Palace's valuation of £70m - and at present they aren't willing to increase their offer.
Palace chairman Steve Parish has been in talks with Newcastle sporting director Paul Mitchell and, with 12 days left of the summer window, it could come down to who blinks first.
Arsenal are preparing for the departure of Aaron Ramsdale, who is wanted by Wolves.

Wolves have submitted an offer to sign Ramsdale on loan with an option to buy. And although Arsenal would rather a permanent sale, the fact they are lining up a replacement suggests the deal could go ahead.
The Athletic says Espanyol's Joan Garcia, 23, has already verbally agreed to join, while the Gunners also want to secure a homegrown third-choice goalkeeper.
Manchester United made Manuel Ugarte their number one target for midfield earlier this summer - and it seems they are close to securing his services.

Ugarte is keen to move to Old Trafford and agreed personal terms back in July. United have remained patient and reports suggest that Jorge Mendes is close to striking a deal with Paris Saint-Germain for a loan with an obligation to buy.
It now seem very likely that the move will go ahead before the deadline on August 31.
Ilkay Gundogan can leave Barcelona before the end of the transfer window - with a potential return to Manchester City on the cards.
The German international's camp has reportedly started exploring options for the final days of the summer transfer window with the Spanish giants now open to letting Gundogan go.
New Barcelona boss Hansi Flick said he expects Gündogan to stay. However, reports now state that solutions are being explored, including a stunning return to City.
The midfielder revealed he 'wants an immediate return' to the Etihad.
Raheem Sterling has three years left on his Chelsea contract, but his omission from Enzo Maresca's squad to face Manchester City on Sunday has turned his world upside down.
With Pedro Neto signed for £54million and Joao Felix on the way in for £36m, the Guardian reports that Sterling fears he may play no further role for his club.

The problem is that Sterling is paid £325,000 per week at Chelsea and finding a buyer this late in the window will prove difficult. Sterling has previously rejected interest from Saudi Arabia, while Juventus interest didn't go far.
Armando Broja, Trevoh Chalobah, Ben Chilwell, Djordje Petrovic, Carney Chukwuemeka and David Datro Fofana are also up for sale at Chelsea, alongside Romelu Lukaku and Kepa Arrizabalaga.

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Frenkie de Jong blow as midfield target makes move
body: Manchester United began their Premier League campaign with a narrow victory over Fulham and Erik ten Hag could yet further bolster his squad before the end of August
Manchester United may well still have work to do despite getting off to a winning start in the Premier League.

Erik ten Hag's side beat Fulham 1-0 at Old Trafford, with new signing Joshua Zirkzee the match-winner. Noussair Mazraoui made his full debut at the back, with Zirkzee and Matthijs de Ligt both coming off the bench in the second half.

The move for De Ligt was accelerated after another of United's summer signings, Leny Yoro, picked up an injury in pre-season. With striker Rasmus Hojlund also sidelined, United could also look for reinforcements in attack.
Links with Paris Saint-Germain's Manuel Ugarte haven't gone away either, with a new midfielder potentially on the cards. Here are Mirror Football's latest lines from around Old Trafford.

Manchester United's links with Frenkie de Jong have been quieter this year than in the past, but not invisible. Talk has grown louder in recent weeks, but a move appears tough - especially if Barcelona allow Ilkay Gundogan to leave this summer.

According to reports in Spain, Gundogan has indicated he's ready to leave Camp Nou after just one season. Turkey or Saudi Arabia could provide an exit route for the German international, who impressed in his first year after a free transfer from Manchester City.

Barcelona boss Hansi Flick has held talks with his compatriot and suggests it's more likely than not that Gundogan will stay. If Barca decide it's time to take the big earner off their wage bill, though, it's hard to see a second midfield departure following.

"When the Club is looking for you like AC Milan was looking for me, it's obvious you want to go there," he said. headline: Erik ten Hag sent pointed message after Man Utd transfer target finds new club
body: Manchester United were heavily linked with Youssouf Fofana, but the midfielder has instead signed for AC Milan from Monaco and sent a pointed message about the move
Manchester United were interested in signing Youssouf Fofana this summer, but the midfielder has joined AC Milan instead.
Fofana was among several options being explored by United, along with PSG's Manuel Ugarte and Burnley star Sander Berge, but the France international has now completed a £21.3million move to Milan.

And Fofana appears to have sent a pointed message to United when discussing why he chose Milan, highlighting the fact they will be playing Champions League football this season while the Red Devils are in the Europa League.

"When the club is looking for you like AC Milan was looking for me, it's obvious you want to go there," Fofana said. "This is the right moment, for me and the squad: now I am a complete player, I want to play in the Champions League and win the Scudetto, I cannot wait to start.
"The project I saw from the club aligns with my ideas. I spoke with Fonseca, he told me he is happy to have me in his side and that he can't wait to get to work with me.

"When I played against him in France, it was always hard, also as he played a different kind of football to what we had in Ligue 1. We aren't here to promise anything to the fans, I am here at AC Milan to win."

Fofana also revealed he spoke to his France team-mates Theo Hernandez and Mike Maignan about joining Milan. "I went and asked them about the club, the city, but also other French players have spoken well about Milan," he added.
"I think their words influenced my decision. I am not here to replace anyone, I am myself: a modern midfielder who has work to do in both halves of the pitch.

"This evening, the league begins, and I want to play already, people often say that waiting makes the desire stronger, and now I am happy to be here with you. I have been patient, and today I am at AC Milan. There is no best version of me, I hope I can improve year after year."

Academy graduate Will Fish has agreed a move to Championship side Cardiff City as United continue to trim down their first-team squad with Scott McTominay also thought to be attracting interest - both at home and abroad.

United have signed Noussair Mazraoui, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Joshua Zirkzee so far this summer. PSV have grown concerned over his injury record and are said to have 'completely discarded' the idea of signing him.

Truffert came through the same Rennes youth ranks that produced Eduardo Camavinga, Ousmane Dembele, Mathys Tel, Sylvain Wiltord and Mikael Silvestre among others. He is under contract until 2026.

The window is starting to wrap up but United look set to be busy up until deadline day.
If you were Erik ten Hag, who would you be looking to keep and sell in the summer transfer window?

Joshua Zirkzee's goal was very lucky but his start could be a sign of many things to come for him. Man United could have killed the game earlier on, Zirkzee saved the three points for them and I think Erik ten Hag will be very pleased that he's already contributed. Spending all that money on wages and eventually it’s all been sorted. What Ten Hag should’ve done is sit down and have this chat last year. If my son or my daughter are annoyed then we sit down and speak about it. With Sancho we’re talking about a player that cost tens of millions of pounds during a time when United have their backs to the all in terms of performances on the pitch needing all they’ve got to try and get back on track. headline: Manchester United might have to take a hit to make a profit with biggest transfer sale
body: It was three, rather than two, attack-minded substitutions by Erik ten Hag that procured Manchester United's victory against Fulham.
Alejandro Garnacho crossed for Joshua Zirkzee, who prodded the ball ahead of the expertly-placed Scott McTominay.
McTominay has form for that. Cast your mind back to Casemiro's added-time equaliser at Chelsea in October 2022 and his nearest 'marker' was McTominay, directly behind him.

The Scot scored ten goals for United last season and all of them were big. Two beyond the 90th minute against Brentford, two against Chelsea, a winner against Aston Villa, FA Cup quarter and semi-final goals, the opener at Sheffield United and restoring two-goal advantages at Galatasaray and Wolves.
That extended to the European Championship in Germany, where he became only the sixth Scotland international to register at a Euros.

A 27-year-old United-bred Premier League proven international with goal-getting nous and robust fitness is a valuable player. Only United overestimated McTominay's value last year when they knocked back West Ham United's offer of £30million. McTominay was inexplicably valued at £40m.
The sums did not add up. McTominay started only 16 games in Ten Hag's first season and had been rumbled by the United manager, who favoured midfield technicians.
The latest was Kobbie Mainoo, only Rodrygo collided into his ankle during pre-season last year and Mainoo did not represent the first team again for another four months. That reprieved McTominay.
And so one of United's biggest players last season was a player they had planned to sell. They still plan on doing so but are running out of time.
United may take a dim view of Fulham offering a larger overall fee for the twice-relegated Sander Berge of Burnley. Berge is only 14 months younger than McTominay and scored twice last season.
The new United are determined to change their reputation in the market and the days when they gave away players for a tuppence are over. Fulham's last offer of £23m for McTominay was derisory.

The bigger picture is United cannot command much more than that. McTominay's contract has a maximum expiry date of 2026 but he would have to have a stonking season to maintain his resale value in 12 months' time.

United also want to reinforce their midfield with a more balanced addition in Manuel Ugarte. McTominay is a proven game-changer but he jars with whatever game model United are attempting to implement.
McTominay's game revolves around net-busting and bustling. United are seeking a more refined approach and their only defensive midfielder is a 32-year-old who now prefers to attack.

Last year, United banked a derisory £15m up front rising to £20m for Dean Henderson. Chelsea offered £40m for Henderson in 2021, the summer Ole Gunnar Solskjaer promised to install him as United's No.1. The supine Solskjaer reneged on that when Henderson recovered from Covid-19.

Like with his academy teammate Henderson, United have to take a hit to make a profit on McTominay. They will now do well to get £25m, especially as Fulham do not plan on tabling another offer if they sign Berge.

Only five United players have been sold for fees of £25m and above: David Beckham, Cristiano Ronaldo, Angel di Maria, Romelu Lukaku and Daniel James. Mason Greenwood would become the sixth if his add-ons are triggered.

Overseas clubs have fluttered their eyelashes at McTominay but most have received short shrift as they do not have the funds to meet United's asking price. As much as Jose Mourinho wanted to reunite with him, McTominay was not keen on the prospect of relocating to Istanbul.
He was receptive to moving to London last year. McTominay's girlfriend's family hail from nearby Bromley and that is thought to have had a bearing.

Some members of McTominay's family were miffed by his treatment at the start of last season. So much so one of the family regulars at Old Trafford was not in attendance for the remarkable recovery against Brentford when McTominay struck in the 93rd and 97th minute.

Lancaster-born McTominay's attachment to United dates back to the age of five when he joined their development centre. He has spent seven-and-a-half years in the first team and endeared himself to managers as diverse as Mourinho, Solskjaer, Ralf Rangnick and Ten Hag.

A teammate once disparagingly referred to McTominay as a "teacher's pet". That was a compliment. McTominay has fared far better under all four managers than said teammate through a mentality that has taken him a long way.
And contributed to Friday night's winner.

headline: 'That is utopia' - Manchester United plotting first-team debuts after historic academy season
body: Manchester United's academy building at Carrington is currently a hive of activity.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe's project to renovate the main building, which is costing £50million, began in June and the senior players are sharing the youth building while construction is ongoing.
There is a tangible buzz around the academy building and the Manchester Evening News were recently invited through its doors to speak with Under-21 manager Travis Binnion.

Binnion has been generous with his time since taking charge of the U21s and discussed the likes of Toby Collyer, Ethan Wheatley, Harry Amass, and how INEOS have impacted the academy during the interview, which was ahead of the youngsters' game against Barnsley in the EFL Trophy.

"Over the last year, those two players you mentioned, Amass and Wheatley, have progressed a lot, a hell of a lot," Binnion said. "Ethan Wheatley in particular has turned into a real eye-catching centre forward and his profile is one that managers like because he’s lean, quick and tall.
"If you drew a No.9, you’d draw him looking like Ethan, but his game has come on leaps and bounds, so knowing where to run and his link-up play has improved, and being in better positions.

"He’s spent around 12 to 13 weeks consistently training with the first-team, just like Harry, and I think within that environment, particularly when you’re having to play like they did in pre-season, you’re able to learn quicker. The good players always do in that situation.

"Equally, if you find it hard in that environment, it can be an unforgiving place to be because the level is possibly too high if you’re struggling. You find out a lot about yourself in terms of your game, but you also find out a lot about yourself as a person and as a professional as well."
Wheatley and Amass were both taken on the USA pre-season tour and were given opportunities by Erik ten Hag, who named them in a handful of first-team squads last season.
Both are highly regarded at United and Wheatley is seen as a young striker with vast potential, while some have predicted Amass could become Luke Shaw's long-term successor.
"Harry’s very good on the ball, he can defend well, but he knows a big part of his game is wider defending to ensure he deals with movement and defending space in behind," said Binnion.
"His game in possession is in a really good place and he’s physically capable, but he knows that he’s got to keep working, as most full-backs have, in their defensive moments."
Collyer was another youngster to stand out during pre-season and Ten Hag said he'd 'earned' his first-team chances when he spoke to reporters before the USA tour.

Last month, Collyer signed a new contract until 2027 and Ten Hag insisted on attending his signing ceremony at Carrington, while the Dutchman was also spotted deep in conversation with him after the FA Cup final, which was reminiscent of his exchange with Kobbie Mainoo.
Collyer's athleticism has impressed staff and his running stats are among the best in each training session, which saw him make his competitive senior debut in the Community Shield.

"If Toby had a clean 18 months and a clean two and a half years with us, we would be talking about a really top young player," Binnion said. "We’re talking about a really good young player with high potential. He joined us from another club and took a little while to get going.

"He couldn’t play in the FA Youth Cup run, so he was here but couldn’t play. He's also had a couple of injuries and nothing terrible, but when you have a spell out of the game and have a couple of injuries that stop you playing, it takes a while to get going, but when we signed him, we had no doubts about what he was capable of - he's a fantastic athlete and effective without the ball.
"Toby is also making great strides with the ball, so we’re talking there about someone who can be really effective in all moments of the game and I think that’s what you saw on tour.
"That's why the manager has involved him in numerous squads. I think he’s earned the trust of the manager and that’s not easy to do, so great credit to him, he’s a fantastic lad.

"He's got a superb attitude and he’s getting what he deserves. We just know the manager really likes him and the conversations I have with Fletch [Darren Fletcher] are along those lines and we talk about what’s right for his development, so what’s next and what does he need to do?"

Kobbe Mainoo was standing outside the academy building, chatting to Hannibal Mejbri, before Binnion arrived for the interview and the U21 boss said the next step for the likes of Wheatley, Amass and Collyer is to emulate how he's established himself as a senior player.
"The challenge for those boys is to become Kobbie, [Alejandro] Garnacho, or Omari Forson, who has left the club now but he was around a lot of matchday squads and featured more than once.

"That’s your first step, train with the first-team all the time, which some of those boys are doing, then it’s to be in multiple squads, then it’s to make multiple appearances and then become an established sort of starter. There are four stages there and that’s if you stay in the building.

"I don’t think there’s a better club in the country to be at to aspire and achieve and see very quickly what you can do. With that comes a great expectation and you’ve got to be good enough, but I really don’t think there’s a better club to be at for the ‘pathway’. People use that word and I don’t like it, but that’s the title that’s given and this is the best club to be at for that."

Mainoo and Garnacho have both previously starred in EFL Trophy fixtures, a competition in which Premier League sides field U21 teams against League One and League Two senior teams, and United get their new campaign under way on Tuesday night against Barnsley.
United will also play Doncaster and Huddersfield in their EFL Trophy group and the U21 side has been followed by a sold-out away support over the last few seasons in the competition.

"My two fondest memories are the FA Youth Cup final, with the brilliant crowd that night, and Stockport away in the EFL Trophy," said Binnion. "Salford was good last season, bar the result, and Fleetwood was great. Garnacho’s late winner at Barrow was great and we can’t shy away from the two drubbings against Bolton, so I’m glad we’re not in their group this year.

"But that was a great learning experience. We are very lucky to work at a football club where the academy is integral and you feel it. There’s an expectation that comes with that, but there’s excitement from the fans that I don’t see from any other club towards its youth players

"The EFL Trophy is the best competition for us, alongside the Youth Cup. They’re the two we’re involved in every year that I think we find the most about the players and the players look forward to most, so that’s a good indicator of the importance it plays within our programme.

"It gives the players a first taste of senior football and a real good opportunity against senior opposition, which brings different challenges, but they also have to deal with the expectation of having to deliver with a different level of challenge, which is obviously greater.

"The good players and the better players thrive in those moments, so I can remember both of those players [Mainoo and Garnacho] delivering high-level moments that gave the manager and fans insight into whether they had the capability of breaking into the first-team.

"It’s all well and good performing for the U18s or in the PL2, but there are certain games when you feel and can see in front of your eyes that players grow. On the other hand, some players don’t deliver the sort of performance you were hoping to see and that’s not terminal.
"But if over three games and two years of playing in that competition, they’ve maybe not delivered or they have, it probably points towards what they will do within the club."
Binnion last spoke to the MEN in May for a season review article and he'd just overseen an academy trip to France that saw United take on the youth team of INEOS-owned Nice.

Since then, INEOS' relationship with United's academy has strengthened and Binnion provided insight into how technical director Jason Wilcox and sporting director Dan Ashworth have been involved since joining from Southampton and Newcastle respectively.

"Dan and Jason have vast experience in the game and their relationship with Nick [Cox] and myself, along with the support from a wider perspective into recruitment from INEOS, only gives the academy more avenues to develop players and have greater depth of experience.

"I think the appointments, the resource and the experience they have, can only make the decision-making process around our players stronger. I've had meetings with both since they joined and they have been very involved in terms of supporting Nick and supporting myself.

"Whether that be from a recruitment, playing style or from a squad planning and loans perspective, they [Wilcox and Ashworth] are across all of that, so before it was [Darren] Fletch, Nick and myself. You've still got the same people involved, but there's now an extra layer from executive level, but we have football people, who have youth football experience, in those roles.

"Any level of expertise can only help us be even more aligned from academy to first-team. It will help us recruit the right players, the environment is important and the profile of our recruitment is important. If you get those right, with the right training programme, then you’ve got utopia."

Binnion had a strong working relationship with Mitchell van der Gaag, Ten Hag's former assistant manager. He departed this summer, but Darren Fletcher has been appointed as a first-team coach and the former United player is now the main conduit between the academy and first-team.
"Fletch has become even more integral in the first-team coaching set-up, so for me now, he was really important in terms of day-to-day involvement, loans and player minutes," said Binnion.

"I got close to Mitchell about what he saw each day, but with Fletch increasing his amount of coaching, I’ve kind of got one person to deal with now for almost everything, so Mitchell has gone and that’s happened, but Fletch is doing more and that’s only a good thing for our younger players."
The transfer window shuts in 10 days and a few academy players could leave on loan before the deadline. "There could and should be two or three exits on loan," said Binnion.
"I won’t say who because those players are because they could be disappointed if they stay in the building, but as I’ve stressed previously, the loans have to be right for them.
"We’ve seen previous loans of just getting the boys out of the building are not good enough. They need to get out there, play, learn and get the opportunity to develop.
"If we don’t get those opportunities, it can be a stagnant part of a player’s career, or if you get two poor loans in a row, it can be really quite detrimental to a player’s progress."

headline: Man United are replicating Man City in the transfer market - and there's one clear reason why
body: Even with five injuries to contend with, the Manchester United squad against Fulham was strong enough that two international wingers were omitted.

Facundo Pellistri is unlikely to be named in a United matchday party again and several supporters will hope Jadon Sancho's absence extends to Brighton and beyond. Erik ten Hag clarified Sancho was fit enough to be involved on Friday evening, despite suffering an ear infection last week.

Ideally, United would recruit three more players. Realistically, it will be one - a midfielder. If Pellistri and Sancho both go, United have first and second-choice wingers on both flanks. Ditto the peripheral Hannibal Mejbri; Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount are ahead of him as No.10s.

Victor Lindelof has played two halves of football since he reported for pre-season six weeks ago and done minimal training. He was nursing a "niggle" and then came off against Liverpool as a "precaution". Now he is on crutches. That's a nasty niggle.
READ MORE:Zirkzee has already given United something they did not have last season

Lindelof, 30, is borderline unsellable. He missed 21 games last season through injury, has started this season out injured and is out of contract next year. Takers will not be queuing around the block.

United at least have four senior centre halves in his absence. The enforced withdrawals of Noussair Mazraoui and Harry Maguire (both building up their fitness) in the 81st minute could have destabilised the defence against Fulham. Matthijs de Ligt and Jonny Evans ensured United's shop remained shut after Joshua Zirkzee scored. Leny Yoro will return after the clocks go back.

Provided Luke Shaw does not suffer an umpteenth setback, he is due back after the September internationals, so United will hope to get by with Mazraoui and Diogo Dalot at full back against Brighton and Liverpool. Tyrell Malacia's early October return date should be lightly pencilled in and United have Harry Amass as an alternative.

It was apparent at the start of this summer United would not break the £60million barrier for a signing and the final fee for Yoro was just shy of that. For years, Manchester City prided themselves on not exceeding £60m for a signing and only four additions (Rodri, Ruben Dias, Jack Grealish and Josko Gvardiol) have fetched fees above that. The common denominator, of course, is Omar Berrada.
United's current summer outlay stands at £155.35m (including add-ons), with an up-front sum of £139.98m. United sources have stressed this is the summer of budget discipline and swift market action.

Scott McTominay, the only truly sellable asset in midfield, has to make room for an incoming, preferably Manuel Ugarte. United are confident of getting Ugarte but it is understood to be contingent on McTominay going.

United should not be shortchanged for an academy graduate and proven Premier League player with matchwinning nous and international pedigree, yet McTominay's contract situation forces their hand. They likely have to take a hit on a player valued at £40m last year to make a profit this year.

Whatever United's game model is (Ten Hag mentioned his new buzz phrase twice during his tour sit-down and twice again at Carrington on Thursday), McTominay jars with it. He is an industrious impact player but not a technician and he might have gone a year earlier had Kobbie Mainoo not hobbled off in Houston 13 months ago.

Ten Hag has stressed the need for quantity and quality. Toby Collyer has emerged as an additional option in midfield, an area where at least five out-and-out options are required. Discounting Mount, United already have a quintet with an average age lowered by Mainoo and pre-season tour breakout Collyer. Ten Hag can also call upon Fernandes, arguably a better footballer in the middle third than the final third.

This is a season where the minimum aim for United has to be a top four finish. There have been too many like that in the past decade (2014-15, 2019-20, 2022-23) but United have not challenged for the championship since they last won it.

United's squad is still not where it needs to be though they were never going to complete their gradual rebuild in one summer. The two senior left backs are crocks, two of their midfielders are creaking and there is not a dependable goalscorer in the frontline.

Ducks must be lined up for next summer: Evans, Lindelof and Eriksen can be released. Maguire could be, depending on his form this term, Casemiro should be easier to shift and a succession plan at left back is warranted with Shaw clocking up more days in the medical centre than on the training pitch at Carrington. Malacia, out of contract in 2026, is vulnerable.

Provisionally, United will need a centre back, a left back and two midfielders next summer. Maybe an extra forward if wayward wingers Marcus Rashford and Antony do not improve over the next nine months. Two wingers could already be going this month.

headline: Manchester United player's mistake at Wembley was his final contribution before summer exit
body: Facundo Pellistri was caught sleeping at the back post and Bernardo Silva equalised.
The Community Shield is considered a glorified pre-season friendly, but Pellistri's lack of alertness at Wembley opened the door for Manchester City to win the game on penalties.
Pellistri was introduced to the game from the bench in the second half and he played at right-back, which was interesting given he had never played in that role previously.

The goal might have been prevented if Harry Amass had started at left-back, as Diogo Dalot would have lined up on the opposite side and would have dealt with the cross to the back post, although that is completely hypothetical and nobody is losing sleep over the Community Shield.
The defeat on penalties at Wembley has already been forgotten about, but Pellistri's mistake looks like his final contribution in red because he's nearing a switch to Panathinaikos.
Pellistri was absent from United's squad for their 1-0 win against Fulham on the opening day of the season and is understood to be wanted by Panathinaikos on a permanent transfer.
The 22-year-old's contract with United expires next summer and a departure in this window was always likely, despite the club having the option to extend his deal by another year.

Pellistri spent the second half of last season on loan with Granada and seemed to find his level. That move represented his third loan move away after two previous stints with Deportivo Alavés and leaving on so many temporary deals suggested his future was away from United.

United paid £9million to sign Pelistri four years ago and the player's market value has been protected by his performances for Uruguay's national team on the right wing, but except for a few positive displays as a substitute, he's never convinced during his time in Manchester.

Although there was a clamour among supporters to see more of Pellistri at the beginning of last season and he was given a huge opportunity when starting against Bayern Munich away from home Munich in the Champions League, he fluffed his lines and never recovered.
Pellistri was effective when entering games from the bench, which helped him take advantage of tired legs, but he couldn't shake off his reputation as an impact substitution.

His opportunities became limited in the winter and it was no surprise to see him leave on loan in the January window. It's also not a surprise that United prefer a permanent sale of Pellistri this summer, despite having the option of extending his contract by an extra year.
The one-year extension in Pellistri's contract could be triggered and he could be sent on loan again, with the hope of increasing his resale value, but there won't be much upside.

United need to sell more players before August 30 to generate funds and operate within PSR rules and cashing in on Pellistri is logical to help balance the books, especially when considering that Victor Lindelof may be unable to be sold, depending on the severity of his injury.
It's thought Panathinaikos have submitted an offer that means United will recoup most of the £9m they invested into signing Pellistri and that might be good enough to seal the deal.

A permanent sale of Pellistri for a fee in that region would take the money raised from sales to around £70m, providing the add-on related bonuses are triggered in the other sales (Alvaro Fernandez, Donny van de Beek, Willy Kambwala, Mason Greenwood and Aaron Wan-Bissaka).
United have been criticised for failing to clear out their dead wood in the last 10 years but they have been proactive in the selling market this summer to raise funds to reinvest.
Pellistri never fulfilled his potential at United and nobody will be unhappy at his departure.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo tipped for shock Man United return to resolve 'unfinished business'
body: Cristiano Ronaldo could make a shock return to Manchester United as a coach or manager, according to his former teammate Louis Saha.

Ronaldo's name is forever linked with United due to his incredible first spell at Old Trafford. However, his second stint was less fruitful, culminating in a controversial departure following an infamous interview with Piers Morgan.

Ronaldo is currently playing for Al-Nassr in Saudi Arabia and will turn 40 next year. His future plans, both at the club level and internationally ahead of the 2026 World Cup in the United States, remain unconfirmed.

Despite his notorious 'coaching' from the sidelines during Portugal's Euro 2016 final victory, Ronaldo has not publicly expressed any interest in a managerial career. Yet, this hasn't stopped Saha from envisioning him in the dugout, potentially at Old Trafford.
"Cristiano Ronaldo has the passion and dedication to return to Manchester United one day," Saha shared with TVSporten. "That could be as a coach or even a manager.

"His second spell didn't end how everyone had hoped, and you can see why that frustrated him. He didn't see the same formula and didn't see the passion from young players that he had been used to seeing."

Ronaldo's second spell at United was tumultuous, marked by playing under three different managers and criticising the club and its hierarchy before his release in November 2022. The legendary forward's interview with Morgan was the catalyst for his departure from United, with his criticism of Erik ten Hag and the club's younger players being the final straw.

Despite this, Ronaldo managed to net 27 goals in 54 matches in his second stint, after scoring 118 goals on the way to Premier League and Champions League success in his first spell. He has since been thriving at Al Nassr in Saudi Arabia, scoring an impressive 35 goals in his debut season.

While he is expected to remain at Al Nassr for the current campaign, his plans beyond that are uncertain. Former United colleague Saha believes Ronaldo could transition into coaching, provided he refines some of his interpersonal skills.
"Now he will know that he needs to find a new way to communicate when he becomes a coach," Saha added. "Which maybe isn't as harsh or direct as it was when he was at the club.

"He will work out how to be successful and use all his knowledge to do that; we've seen Roy Keane go into management and have success. Cristiano will understand what he needs to do as a manager. I see no reason why he wouldn't be a success."

headline: 'I love him' - Manchester United dealt fresh midfielder transfer blow
body: Manchester United have been told Fiorentina plan to hold onto Sofyan Amrabat past the transfer deadline.

Amrabat spent last season on loan at United from Fiorentina after the Reds agreed a €10million (£8.5million) loan fee for the midfielder. The deal also included the option of making the move permanent for a fee worth up to €25million (£21million) including add-ons.

United continue to be in the market for a new midfielder, with Paris Saint-Germain star Manuel Ugarte the club's top target. The Reds had the option to make Amrabat's move permanent but that was not triggered and he returned to Fiorentina after making 30 appearances in all competitions during his loan spell.

A return to Old Trafford has not been ruled as United have until August 30 to complete their transfer business and the Manchester Evening News understands Amrabat is still under consideration. However, the Morocco international's manager at Fiorentina has outlined the determination to keep the player in Italy for this season.
Fiorentina manager Raffaele Palladino has given an update on Amrabat's future and explained why he hopes the former United loanee remains at the club beyond this summer.
"I love him [Amrabat], he's a great guy, we've created a great relationship with him," Palladino told TuttomercatoWeb.
"He's a sincere guy at heart. He sent signals to me and Fiorentina, making himself available from day one.
"The transfer rumours are normal, he's a player of a certain level, he and the club will decide his future. I hope I can still coach him, for me he's a great player".

United have already made signed four new players this summer to strengthen Erik ten Hag's squad. Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui have all been signed and there is still the realistic possibility of further additions being made before the transfer window closes later this month.

headline: Ivan Toney to Man United transfer truth as Brentford make reluctant £50m decision
body: Brentford are reportedly resigned to selling Ivan Toney this summer but a move to Manchester United looks to be unlikely.

The England international has made no secret about his intention to depart the Bees since coming back from his betting ban in January. Toney had stressed he wanted a move to a 'big club' who were challenging for Premier League titles after acknowledging that at 28 he had limited chances remaining to make a 'big move'.

On Sunday, the striker was not named in the Brentford squad that beat Crystal Palace 2-1 and his manager Thomas Frank explained why he was absent. "A lot of things are going on with Ivan, especially with transfers, there’s a lot of transfer interest," he said.
"Because of all that, we’ve decided not to include him in the squad. I can’t give too much away the day before.
"Of course, Ivan is a top player, we all know that. He has been fantastic for us for four years but we showed last season we can cope without him."
Toney had been linked with United due to the Reds only having two recognised strikers in their squad - Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee. However, it appears Toney's future will lie in Saudi Arabia.

The Times reports Brentford are resigned to the idea of losing Toney with Saudi Pro League club Al Ahli the favourites to complete a deal. It is believed a fee of £50m will be demanded by the Bees who were understandably reluctant to let their centre-forward leave.

As for United, they are unlikely to make another forward signing this summer. MEN Sport understands the only likely incoming is a central midfielder but a move for PSG's Manuel Ugarte is being postponed until an existing player, expected to be Scott McTominay, is sold.

headline: £40m deal, major issue solved - Seven transfers Man United can complete this week
body: Transfer dominos are beginning to topple as the summer window edges towards the final week of business.

Manchester United are expected to be busy, whether it's incomings or outgoings, Erik ten Hag has decisions to make. Question marks were raised over Jadon Sancho's future after he was left out of the squad that beat Fulham 1-0 on the opening day, thanks to a Joshua Zirkzee debut goal.

The United boss revealed that the 24-year-old was not included partly due to an eat infection. But the future of the attacker is not the only one that is unclear with speculation surrounding Scott McTominay, Facundo Pellistri and Victor Lindelof, meanwhile, rumours ramp up over potential incomings such as Manuel Ugarte and Sander Berge.
Fulham have reportedly set their sights on Burnley midfielder Sander Berge. The Cottagers are said to be rivalling United for the Norwegian, over a possible deal worth £25million.

Ten Hag's side were rumoured to have held talks with the 26-year-old as he missed the Clarets first two Championship matches. Manager Scott Parker insisted it was down to injury but the absence came in light of the speculation over his future.
The aforementioned dominos have fallen, reports have suggested that Fulham turned their attention to Berge after moving away from the table over a deal for McTominay.

Marco Silva's side have reportedly already had a £20m bid rebuffed by United for McTominay. The Scotland played a key role off the bench during parts of last season for Ten Hag's side and has faced scrutiny over his future at Old Trafford.
Napoli are said to be interested but prefer a loan move. The 27-year-old has 12 months remaining on his current deal but has an option of a further year included in his contract.
The MEN understands that truce was made between the two parties The Paris Saint-Germain midfielder was omitted from the squad for their Ligue 1 curtain-raiser against Le Havre on Friday.
Following transfer business this summer from Luis Enrique's side, which has seen highly-rated midfielder Joao Neves enter the fray, the future of Ugarte appears precarious.

Ugarte would be the perfect linchpin to deputise alongside Kobbie Mainoo, not only would his signature be an exciting one but it would be a continuation of the promising additions made at Old Trafford this summer. At 23, his best years are to come.
Cardiff City are set to sign Manchester United defender Will Fish.

The 21-year-old is another player with one year, plus the option of an extension, remaining on his contract. After a loan spell in the Scottish Premiership with Hibernian, the defender was eyeing regular football with the influx of options in the defensive department at Carrington.

The sale marks a shift from clubs this summer to cash in on the assets that were forged in the academy, and for United, it's valuable funds to, not only, the transfer budget but the Profit and Sustainability accounts.

United are confident of signing Manuel Ugarte this summer further limiting Pellistri's opportunities. The Uruguayan has failed to break into a first-team starting berth and is on his way out of United.
Pellistri spent time on loan in La Liga with Granada before he looked set for another temporary spell away last season until an injury to Amad curtailed plans of an exit.
Greek giants Panathinaikos are seemingly the frontrunners to sign the attacker with a fee in the region of €6million (£5m) being reported elsewhere.

Jadon Sancho was back to his best last season as he helped Borussia Dortmund to the Champions League final. Although it was disappointment for the Bundesliga club, suffering defeat to the impervious Real Madrid, Sancho stamped his mark on European football at the place where he earned a feared reputation.

Famed for his attacking prowess and creativity, it seemingly diminished after his big-money move to United. Issues and problems followed before a fall-out with Ten Hag put an end to his first-team involvement.

Returning to United, a truce was made between the two parties but speculation has continued to swirl over the England international. PSG are said to be among the clubs looking at acquiring Sancho, whether it is on a permanent deal or a loan remains unclear.

headline: 'Help us win trophies' - Erik ten Hag gives exciting verdict on Manchester United's two new signings
body: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag believes Leny Yoro can help the club to 'win trophies' when he returns from injury and he also lavished praise on Joshua Zirkzee.
Zirkzee was the first signing of the summer at Old Trafford and he sealed a €42.5m (£36.5m) move from Bologna last month, signing a five-year contract that will expire in 2029.

Yoro joined from Lille in a deal worth €62m (£52.8m) plus €8m (£6.8m) in add-ons on and impressed on his first appearance in pre-season, but disaster struck in his next game when the defender fractured his metatarsal against Arsenal, an injury that required surgery.
The Frenchman is not expected to return from the sidelines until October and was standing on crutches when he was introduced to the Old Trafford crowd before the Fulham game.
Yoro's return from injury is something for supporters to look forward to and Ten Hag, speaking to SuperSport, said he is 'sure' the centre-back will help United win trophies in the future.
"We are so happy that we could sign him, he's one the biggest assets in European football, so we managed to bring him in and we are very pleased," said Ten Hag about Yoro.
"Leny knows he has to progress a lot and we know must help and support him, and we know we have the skills in our team to help him to achieve his high ambition.
"The potential is absolutely there and we are sure he can help us win games, we are sure he can help us to win trophies. That's what United stands for."
When Ten Hag was asked about Zirkzee, who scored on his debut against Fulham, he added: "He's still a young player, but he's already had an impressive career so far.

"He played in Germany, played in Belgium, Italy, so he's already had experience and is now coming to the Premier League. He has a great skillset for such a big guy. He's got a great technical skillset and a great intuition of play, he can be very creative and I think he really fits well into this club."

Ten Hag also discussed his hopes for the season and the new football structure that has been implemented by Sir Jim Ratcliffe. "What's good is I always want to drive forward, I want to have the feeling that we're accelerating, that there's ambition and a plan," he said.
"In this moment, with this structure, there is a lot of energy and it's exciting, a lot of vision as well to drive this project. We are here to win, it's United, you are here to give a trophy.
"But of course, we want to keep away from all the injuries because then life is easier and easier to achieve the high targets. The project is about building, working and constructing.

"We talk also about what we want to achieve and we are so highly ambitious, we want to go for the highest and do it in a certain way, playing football so we're hard to beat, dynamic, proactive and aggressive. They are the words we want to hear after our performances."

headline: How Manuel Ugarte transfer can unlock Kobbie Mainoo at Manchester United
body: Manchester United are looking to secure the signing of Paris Saint-Germain's Manuel Ugarte before the summer transfer window closes on August 30.

Personal terms have been agreed with the Uruguayan for some time but agreeing a transfer fee with PSG for the midfielder has been a sticking point. Another potential obstacle is the future of Scott McTominay with Ugarte's arrival at Old Trafford said to be contingent on his departure.

But if a deal can be agreed for the 23-year-old, Erik ten Hag may have his most important summer signing. Ugarte's impact on Kobbie Mainoo's game may be transformative for the teenager and United's midfield.

Mainoo is widely regarded as a generational talent and one of the best players to come through United's academy in years. A 19-year-old doesn't get called up to the England squad at Euro 2024 unless they are a special talent.

However, despite enjoying a breakthrough season in 2023/24 in which Mainoo emerged as United's great saviour, one flaw emerged. The ageing and labouring Casemiro in midfield struggled badly in his second season at United.

The Brazilian's lack of mobility often saw huge gaps in midfield as the Reds were exposed repeatedly, leading to a huge number of shots on Andre Onana's goal. Only relegated Sheffield United conceded more shots in the Premier League last season.

And Mainoo's game was impacted, with the Stockport midfielder needing to offer greater protection to United's back four, limiting his ability to influence the attacking play. In fairness to Casemiro, the 32-year-old has looked much improved in the early stages of 24/25 but he cannot be relied upon for another gruelling campaign.

It's why signing Ugarte is so important to unlocking Mainoo's full potential. The Uruguay international will be able to do a lot of the defensive work in midfielder which will free up Mainoo to have a greater impact in attack.

United will no longer be limited in how their midfield functions with greater mobility to cover the spaces which Casemiro could not do. With Ugarte's arrival, Ten Hag's team will finally have what they have missed so badly.

headline: Manchester United's Hannibal Mejbri transfer preference amid Burnley interest
body: Manchester United would prefer a permanent sale of Hannibal Mejbri before the transfer deadline.

The one-year extension in Hannibal's contract was triggered in December, which means he's entered the final year of his deal and United are looking to offload him this summer. Burnley are interested in signing Hannibal and are exploring a permanent deal or a loan with an obligation to buy, but United's preference would be to sell him permanently.

Hannibal started against Burnley at Turf Moor in the Premier League in September and clocked 12.9 kilometres during the game, which was a record for a United player since they began gathering the data in 2019, and more distance than anyone else on the pitch that night.
Hannibal looked to have broken into the first-team fold at one stage but was taken out of the side and his start against Burnley was the only time he made the league XI last season.

Sources described 'wide interest' in both loan and permanent transfers for Hannibal last summer, but the decision was taken to keep him around Erik ten Hag's squad following a promising loan spell with Birmingham in 2022-23 that saw the Tunisian make 41 appearances in all competitions.

United fought off interest from Tottenham, Barcelona and Bayern Munich to sign a young Hannibal from Monaco in a deal worth £9million in 2019. The 21-year-old progressed through the youth ranks and won United's Denzil Haroun Reserve-Team Player of the Year award for his performances in the 2020/21 campaign.

United hoped Hannibal would develop into a first-team starter, but he's been unable to nail down a regular starting place and his opportunities under Ten Hag became limited. Hannibal joined Sevilla on a six-month loan in the January transfer window and the Spaniards had the option to sign him permanently for £17million. But the move didn't go to plan as Hannibal managed just 100 minutes across six appearances and the option wasn't triggered.

Hannibal's loan got off to a bizarre start when Sevilla announced he wouldn't be considered for selection just over a week after his arrival and the picture gradually got murkier. There were claims of differences between Hannibal and manager Quique Sánchez Flores and a suggestion he had a bust-up with a teammate during a training session.

But Sevilla's president denied those reports, praised Hannibal's character and he was reintegrated into their squad. United and Birmingham sources have previously given Hannibal a glowing character appraisal and he is known to stay late at Carrington to complete extra work after training.

headline: 'They will be' - Pep Guardiola explains what Manchester United's four new signings will bring
body: Pep Guardiola believes Manchester United's four new signings will provide momentum and help Erik ten Hag to steer his side into the Premier League top four this season.

United have signed Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui this summer and are looking to sign a midfielder before the transfer deadline on August 30. Mazraoui made his full debut in the 1-0 victory against Fulham on Friday and Zirkzee scored the matchwinner from off the bench.

De Ligt was also introduced to the game as a substitute and those new arrivals all played their part in claiming three points on the opening day of the season. Yoro was unveiled to the Old Trafford crowd before the game and he stood on crutches following a successful surgery on the metatarsal injury that he sustained in pre-season.

The young defender, who was signed from Lille for an initial €62m, is expected to return to action in October and will attempt to help United qualify for Champions League football again. That is the minimum target for Ten Hag and Guardiola recently told reporters he expects United to be in contention for top four and to have 'momentum' after their summer transfers.

“Always at the beginning of the season, the first target is to finish in the top four,” Guardiola said about the tough competition in the Premier League this season. “People say: ‘Oh, come on’, I say ‘no’. Newcastle are not in Europe, and are going to play one game a week. Newcastle with one game a week this season will be the Newcastle of two seasons ago.
“Arsenal are not necessary to talk about. Liverpool are not necessary to talk about. I know the signings of United, they are going to take the momentum and they will be there.
“Tottenham, I’m pretty sure they invest and with the young players and the manager knows better. There are a lot of teams - Chelsea again, the amount of players and their quality and the manager.

“Six or seven teams will be there and if you drop a little bit, you will be away. This is the reality that I have felt since the first season I arrived here and after we proved to ourselves that we can do it and to try to do it again. It’s simple.”

United finished eighth in the Premier League last term, which represented their worst finish in the top flight, and were eight points adrift from the Champions League places. The bookmakers have made City, Arsenal, Liverpool and United their favourites to finish in the top four, with Chelsea and Tottenham priced as the most likely after that.
Aston Villa qualified for the Champions League last season but many expect Unai Emery's side to drop off, just like Newcastle did after playing in Europe's premium competition.

headline: Ruud van Nistelrooy shows Manchester United true colours with three-word verdict of Fulham win
body: Manchester United assistant coach and former striker Ruud van Nistelrooy has given the club's win in the opening match of the season his own seal of approval after Joshua Zirkzee's late winner secured all three points against Fulham on Friday night.

United were hoping to get their third season under manager Erik ten Hag off to a positive start but it took until the 87th minute for them to truly get going after a myriad of missed opportunities for both sides went begging.

Zirkzee started the move, picking the ball up in the Fulham half before playing it out to Casemiro on the right-hand side. The Brazilian found Alejandro Garnacho whose cross was then expertly poked home by United's new centre-forward, who sent Old Trafford into raptures.

After the game, Zirkzee highlighted his delight with his debut goal, claiming it was: "A great feeling, a great feeling, it couldn’t be any better. What can I say? Debut, winning, scoring in front of the Stretford End, so yeah, it’s unbelievable. Where does this moment rank?

"Somewhere between my debuts and it’s a bit below winning the Champions League with Bayern and my national team debut, but it’s up there. I'm just trying to be the best version I can be, help the team and club, so no specific goals."

Afterwards, Van Nistelrooy was spotted putting his arm around the new United frontman with a huge smile on his face, clearly highlighting his delight with Zirkzee's finish. Posting to social media platform Instagram, Van Nistelrooy then shared a photo of him in the dressing room as well as one of the Old Trafford tunnel which leads out onto the pitch.
The Dutchman posted the two photos alongside the caption: "Great team performance, +3" with red, white and black heart emojis.

headline: Napoli chief makes Scott McTominay transfer admission as Man United sent huge update
body: Napoli sporting director Giovanni Manna has hailed the quality of Scott McTominay and refused to rule out a move for the Manchester United midfielder.

headline: Manuel Ugarte to Man United transfer reality has already been explained by player's agent
body: Manuel Ugarte's agent Jorge Chijane has previously admitted that he's sure the Uruguayan will leave Paris Saint-Germain this summer.

Manchester United are interested in signing the midfielder after agreeing personal terms last month. However, the sticking point is agreeing a transfer fee with PSG who reportedly value Ugarte at £51million.

The 23-year-old has since been left out of Luis Enrique's squad for PSG's opening game of the Ligue 1 season against Le Havre on Friday. That has led to increased speculation that a move to Old Trafford could soon happen with United in need of midfield reinforcements amid uncertainty over Scott Mctominay's future and Casemiro's struggles.

Ugarte is signed to Jorge Mendes' agency, Gestifute, with the Portuguese flying into London last week, reportedly as part of talks over his client's future. But his agent Chijane has already told O Jogo back in May that the Uruguay international is unlikely to stay in Paris.
"There is much talk, but I am still not sure about the club. There are many possibilities on the table," he said.
"It’s almost certain that he won’t stay, it’s sure he’ll leave. I believe the situation will be resolved."

The midfielder shone for Sporting CP two seasons again in the Champions League but has struggled to make an impact in France. Ugarte's struggles in Paris should be of some concern but he shouldn't be written off after one poor season.

Ugarte was also one of the standout players at the Copa America this summer with his performances playing a key role in Uruguay reaching the semi-finals. If a reasonable fee can be agreed with PSG then it's certainly a gamble worth taking.

Defensive midfield was at the heart of a lot of United's problems last season with age and injuries appearing to have caught up with a labouring Casemiro. The Brazilian has been linked with a move to Saudi Arabia and Ugarte could be a perfect replacement.

headline: Gary Neville tells Man United exactly why they should sign Ivan Toney after Brentford snub
body: Gary Neville has admitted that he wants Ivan Toney to stay in the Premier League amid transfer links to Saudi Arabia. The striker has been linked with Manchester United this summer as well as Chelsea and Arsenal.

Earlier this month, it was reported that Saudi Arabia club Al Ahli were keen to bring him to the Saudi Pro League. Toney is now in the final 12 months of his contract at Brentford and looks certain to depart.

After Joshua Zirkzee was signed by United earlier in the window, it was expected that their interest in the England international had cooled. However, an injury to Rasmus Hojlund has meant the Red Devils remain in the market for his signature.

On Sunday, the 28-year-old was left out of Brentford's squad for their 2-1 Premier League win over Crystal Palace. The striker is understood to be fully fit with Thomas Frank confirming his absence was down to transfer interest.
"A lot of things going on with Ivan, there is some transfer interest," Frank told Sky Sports. "Because of that he is not in the squad.
"Ivan is a top player we all know that. He has been a fantastic player for us for four years but we showed last year we could cope without him."

Brentford are expected to prefer to sell the England forward now instead of sanctioning a loan move. Neville, who was speaking on Sky Sports after Toney's exclusion, insisted that his arrival would be an asset to any Premier League club.
"I'd love to see him stay in the Premier League but I've been told he may be going to Saudi Arabia, which would be a shame," he explained.

"In the Premier League, we've enjoyed watching him in the last few years but he probably feels like he needs to exploit this contract more than any other before. He's not had the career of a lot of players have had at his age who play for England, where they'll be earning big money.
"He'll feel like he's got to go and earn the [most] money that he possibly can so he may do that. I'd love him to stay in the PL, he'd be a great asset for another club."

headline: Manchester United receive major blow ahead of transfer deadline as player spotted on crutches
body: Manchester United defender Victor Lindelof was absent from the squad to face Fulham on the opening day of the new season and has been pictured using crutches.
Lindelof wasn't included in the squad for the Community Shield or the 1-0 victory against Fulham on Friday night and last appeared in the final pre-season friendly of the USA tour.
The Swedish international, who has entered the final year of his contract, started against Liverpool in South Carolina on August 4 and was substituted at half-time with a knock.

"Always, we have to see what's going on, the assessment. With Will Fish, it's an impact injury, but we also had to sub at half-time, Jonny Evans, because he was ill. Victor Lindelof was a precaution. So yeah, there are some injuries, but we have to see how bad it will be," said Erik ten Hag.

On Thursday, Ten Hag provided a team news update when he spoke at his press conference at Carrington ahead of facing Fulham, but he didn't clarify Lindelof's injury situation. However, the player's wife, Maja Nilsson Lindelof, has shared a photo of him using a crutch on Instagram with the caption: "Doing everything in slow motion these days."

The one-year extension in Lindelof's contract was triggered in December, and United had been actively looking to sell him this summer to obtain a fee before his deal expires. There are 12 days remaining in the transfer window, and Lindelof being spotted with a clutch could have consequences for United's plan to offload him before the deadline.
If United are unable to sell Lindelof in this summer window, he will be allowed to negotiate terms with an overseas club from January and could leave on a free transfer.

Lindelof made 14 Premier League starts last season and slipped down the central defensive pecking order as Harry Maguire returned to form and regained Ten Hag's trust. He has made 249 appearances for United and is one of the longest-serving players in the club's dressing room.

headline: Manchester United send classy message to academy graduate after serious head injury
body: Manchester United have issued a statement in support of their former midfielder Angel Gomes after he was hospitalised due to a severe head injury sustained while playing for French side Lille.

The Reds academy graduate was contesting an aerial ball when he collided with Reims defender Amadou Kone which resulted in his dismissal from the game. Gomes's teammates formed a protective circle around the former United star and fans from both sides chanted his name for a lengthy period.

After being stretchered off, Gomes was transported by ambulance and the match restarted after 34 minutes. United's statement following the incident read: "Everyone at Manchester United is sending best wishes to former Reds midfielder Angel Gomes, who suffered a serious head injury while playing for Lille on Saturday."

Following Lille's update which confirmed he had regained consciousness, United wrote on X: "Sending love and strength to Angel Gomes, who has been taken to hospital following a collision while playing for Lille. We’re thinking of you, Angel."

After the game, Lille manager Bruno Genesio spoke to the media about the incident and delivered an update on Gomes's condition. "The latest news is rather reassuring, but it's better to be careful," he said.
"Angel asked if he was going to play [next] Saturday. It's a good sign if he has a sense of humour. The match was secondary for me tonight. Angel was conscious when he was carried out.
"I know he spoke, he asked about the result, he showed he's in good spirits, but I think we have to wait a bit."
Lille went on to win 2-0 and after the match, his teammates posed with a shirt adorning the message: 'Courage Angel'.

Gomes left United in 2020, joining the French club before spending a season on loan in Portugal, with Boavista. Despite being hailed as one of the most promising talents of this century by United's academy staff, he struggled to secure a regular spot at the senior level at Old Trafford.
